title: How to Chew With Your Mouth Closed

steps.title: Practice with chewing gum.
steps.content: Practice with chewing gum. Close your mouth and chew with your back teeth. Use one or two sticks of gum for this practice. Remember to breathe through your nose, not through your mouth. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Start out with small portions of food; first soft food, like ice-cream or yogurt.
steps.content: Start out with small portions of food; first soft food, like ice-cream or yogurt. Put a little bit of the food into your mouth. Now close your mouth, chewing with only your back teeth. Chew slowly; this helps you keep your mouth closed.

steps.title: Once you have mastered it with the soft foods, try chewing larger portions at a time, as you would normally eat.
steps.content: Once you have mastered it with the soft foods, try chewing larger portions at a time, as you would normally eat. This is no reason to open your mouth. Still chew with it closed.

steps.title: Move on to the more solid foods now, like fruits, rice, and bread.
steps.content: Move on to the more solid foods now, like fruits, rice, and bread. Follow the same principle: small portions at first, then slowly work your way up. Chew slowly.

steps.title: Once you are past this stage, try the hardest foods, such as granola bars and cereals.
steps.content: Once you are past this stage, try the hardest foods, such as granola bars and cereals. While these may make noise, it is no excuse to open your mouth while chewing.
